column2: Title
column3: 1a. Are learning objectives created and clarified to the reader?
column4: 1b. Is the training delivered in a way that builds trainees' belief in their ability to learn and display trained skills (self-efficacy)?
column5: 1c. Does the training encourage trainees to participate in training to learn rather than to appear capable (promotes a learning orientation)?
column6: 1d. Does the training engage trainees and build their interest?
column7: 1e. Does the training utilize a valid training strategy and design? This involves providing information, giving demonstrations of good and bad behaviors, allowing opportunities to practice, and providing meaningful feedback.
column8: 1f. Does the training allow trainees to use the same cognitive processes that they will have to in the environment this learning should transfer to?
column9: 1g. Does the training keep trainees' attention by allowing trainees to monitor their progress toward goals?
column10: 1h. Does the training encourage trainees to make errors?
column11: 1i. Does the training provide sufficient structure to trainees when allowing them to make decisions about their learning experience?
column12: 1j. Does the training simulation increase psychological fidelity (e.g. job-relevant, technology used fits the task)?
column13: 1k. Does the training use established learning / outcome taxonomies (e.g. affective, cognitive, and/or behavioral indicators)?
column14: 2. Are current studies on AI-enhanced VR training programs utilizing a proper control group?
column15: 3. Do current studies on AI-enhanced VR training programs have a sufficient number of people to make inferences about their effectiveness?
column16: 4. What are the preliminary findings: Does adding AI to VR training result in a better experience for the trainee, greater learning, or better on the job performance than regular VR training?
